text: 【3.1.1.1｜Option B: Refuse Her】
“No.”
I try to keep my tone normal—like I’m declining a meal, not rejecting someone who’s staked her entire self on me.
“…Why?”
She asks softly, but there’s a tremor under it, like a blade pressed against glass.
“Because something’s wrong.”
“You know me too well. You talk like you’ve already said these things to me many times.”
I pause, but force myself to finish.
“It scares me.”
She stares at me for a long time.
It doesn’t look like someone being rejected. It looks like—an outcome arriving on schedule once again.
“Being afraid is normal.”
She actually nods, her tone briefly gentler.
“You’re afraid every time.”
As soon as she says it, she seems to realize she’s slipped. Her mouth tightens, swallowing the word “every” deeper.
“There you go again. What does ‘every time’ mean?”
“It means—”
Her throat moves. Like she’s about to tell the truth—and like that truth would drag both of you under.
“It means I shouldn’t push you.”
She gathers the candles back one by one, slowly. Not just candles—like she’s retracting some fragile hope.
“Then we’ll do it differently.”
“Differently how?”
“You don’t have to eat with me.”
“But tonight, you still need to be somewhere I can see.”
It’s too blunt. Too close to a command—and too close to a plea.
“On what grounds—”
“Because I have a task soon.”
“I might be leaving for a while.”
She pauses, voice dropping lower, like she’s speaking more to herself than to me.
“I don’t want to leave while you still see me as just… some weirdo.”
I can’t answer. She places the last candle back into her cloak, like sheathing a blade.
“Forget it.”
“You don’t have to agree.”
She looks up and suddenly smiles again—there’s something almost defiant in it, like she’s daring fate.
“I’ll find a way to keep you here until tonight.”
She turns and walks toward the stairs.
At the stairway, she pauses for a second—like she wants to turn back and explain something. In the end, she only leaves one sentence behind:
“Don’t avoid me.”
